This paper presents the results of an investigation of three (Cu/La-Si and Cu/Zr-Si) and four (Cu/La-Zr-Si) component oxide systems in aqueous ethanol conversion into 1,3-butadiene, with special accent to the effect of lanthanum in the catalyst composition. The catalysts were characterized by HRTEM, SEM, DR UV−vis, in situ near ambient pressure X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (NAP-XPS), FTIR with pyridine, and TPD-CO2. The high (≥65%) 1,3-butadiene selectivity is achieved during the conversion of both rectified and aqueous ethanol over the studied catalysts. Catalyst activity of the four-component oxide systems depends on an introduction order of the components, which determines acid-base characteristics of the surface. A modification of the Cu/Zr-Si catalyst with lanthanum increases their activity in aqueous ethanol conversion into 1,3-butadiene. The positive effect of lanthanum addition into Cu/Zr-Si catalyst can be explained by the formation of lanthanum-containing base sites like [La–Ö–Si] and [La–Ö–H] being tolerant to the action of water. The differences in the interaction of reaction intermediates with surface Zr- and La-containing sites are found out by C 1 s NAP-XPS measurements, and the effect of H2O on adsorption of carbon coke, ethoxy species and acetaldehyde over the catalyst surface is shown. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ethanol 1,3-Butadiene Copper Lanthanum Zirconium oxide NAP-XPS 1 Introduction 1,3-Butadiene (BD) is an industrially important diene for the synthesis of rubber, elastomers and polymer resins [1,2]. BD is produced by the processing of C4 fraction obtained by steam cracking of naphtha or oxidative dehydrogenation of n-butene [3]. Ethanol conversion according to the following general scheme 1 is a biobased alternative to the petroleum method for BD production [1,4,5]. The key steps of the ethanol-to-butadiene (ETB) process depend on the catalyst nature. Most often, there are ethanol dehydrogenation to acetaldehyde (AA) and aldol condensation of AA to crotonaldehyde [6,7]. The formation of C4 products from ethanol is represented in literature as an aldol condensation of two AA molecules according to the Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism [6,8-10]. However, the possibility of CC coupling according to Eley–Rideal mechanism is also being considered [11–13]. Therefore, the formation of active sites able to activate ethanol into acetaldehyde (or enol) and its further transformation via CC coupling on the catalyst surface is a prerequisite for obtaining an active catalyst for the ETB process. The development of active and selective catalysts for the processing of aqueous ethanol will increase the flexibility of the ETB process, since aqueous ethanol can be obtained from fermentation broth by separation on membranes without expensive rectification [7,8,14,15]. However, there is a number of difficulties when using the ethanol-aqueous solution as the feed. They are caused by the blocking of Lewis acid sites of the catalyst surface, resulting in a decrease in ethanol conversion and BD selectivity [16–18]. Amongst the many catalytic systems, acid-base materials based on ZrO2-SiO2 and doped with the components that accelerate ethanol dehydrogenation reaction (ZnO, Ag, Cu, Au, etc.) are the most promising catalysts for ETB process [6,7,19]. The prospects for adding rare-earth element (REE) compounds to the catalyst composition have been shown in recent works. In particular, Lewandowski et al. [20] and Larina et al. [21] showed that modification of ZnO-ZrO2-SiO2 systems with lanthanum allows to increase BD selectivity and Zn-La-Zr-Si oxide system proved to be highly active in the BD production from aqueous ethanol [17,22–24]. Chen et al. [12,25] presented a possibility to obtain BD from ethanol over LaMnO3/SiO2. Jordison et al. [26] showed a promotional effect of La2O3 in the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst on the formation of 1-butanol, another product of CC coupling during ethanol conversion. In a number of works, the conversion of ethanol and ethanol-acetaldehyde mixture into 1,3-butadiene over oxide and zeolite catalysts doped with cerium [27,28] and yttrium [10,29] have also been studied. Dai et al. [30,31] investigated a series of REE-containing (Y, Ce, Nb, Pr, La) catalysts deposited on dealuminated zeolite beta in the ETB process. The authors stated that in the presence of bimetallic (Zn-Y, Cu-Y, Zn-Ce, Cu-Ce) zeolite catalysts, BD selectivity is higher than 50% reaching 63–81% for 2%Zn-8%Y/beta sample. In contrast, in the presence of zeolite catalysts containing only REE, BD selectivity does not exceed 15%. Thus, the catalytic systems containing REE compounds are promising for the development of highly efficient industrial catalysts for the upgrade of ethanol to C4+ products. Meanwhile, the nature of La-containing active sites in the catalysts directly under reaction conditions and their role during ethanol conversion are yet to be unravelled. Herein, we investigate the effect of lanthanum on the catalytic properties of Cu/La(-Zr)-Si oxide systems in the ETB process using aqueous ethanol. A modification of the Cu/Zr-Si catalyst with lanthanum is shown to increase their activity and BD selectivity in aqueous ethanol conversion into 1,3-butadiene. The formation of lanthanum-containing base sites being tolerant to the action of water is found to be a possible reason for the increase in water tolerance of the catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation Industrial silica (large-pore granular silica gel “KSKG” with the specific surface area of 283 m2•g − 1, pore volume of 0.81 cm3•g–1 and average pore diameter of 12 nm) was pre-treated with a 10% nitric acid solution, washed with distilled water, calcined at 773 K, and used for a preparation of catalyst samples. The introduction of zirconium (6 wt% relative to ZrO2) was carried out by wet-kneading of the silica with zirconium(IV) oxynitrate hydrate (analytical grade), followed by drying (393 K, 2 h) and calcination (773 K, 3 h). The introduction of lanthanum (6 wt%) and copper (1 wt%) into the samples was carried out by impregnation with aqueous solutions of corresponding nitrates (chemically-pure grade) with intermediate drying (393 K, 2 h) and calcination (773 K, 3 h). The samples were marked as Zr(La)-Si, Cu/Zr(La)-Si, Cu/Zr-La-Si and Cu/La-Zr-Si. The introduction order of the components is indicated from right to left. 2.2 Catalyst characterization High-resolution transmission electron microscopic (HRTEM) measurements of the samples were performed using a JEOL TEM microscope (200 kV accelerating voltage). The sample morphology was studied by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) using a Tescan MIRA 3 microscope (30 keV electron beam). A chemical composition mapping analysis was carried out by energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) using a Bruker XFlash detector mounted directly into the SEM. Diffuse reflectance UV–visible (DR UV–vis) spectra of the samples were recorded on a Specord M40 spectrometer (Carl Zeiss, Germany) under ambient conditions. The samples after 5 cycles of catalytic reaction with intermediate regeneration in an air flow at 773 K were used for the study. This allows a more correct display of the state of copper in the samples, since copper can be partially or completely reduced by the reaction mixture. In situ near ambient pressure X-ray photoelectron spectroscopic (NAP-XPS) measurements were performed on a commercial SPECS spectrometer. It consists of a main UHV chamber equipped with a monochromated high-intensity Al Kα X-ray source and a differentially pumped multichannel electron energy analyser (PHOIBOS 150). The samples were inserted in a special reaction cell (NAP cell) installed inside the main UHV chamber, referred to as the analysis chamber. During the measurements, the NAP cell was docked to the analyser using a special NAP cell manipulator. In order to decrease the surface charging, the samples were prepared by pressing the catalyst powder onto a tungsten mesh. The catalyst was heated to 773 K in an oxygen flow (1 mbar) for 1 h, then the temperature was lowered to 648 K and the catalyst was reduced in a hydrogen flow (1 mbar). The XPS spectra were obtained as the samples were exposed to 96 vol% ethanol (1 mbar) and a mixture of the ethanol (0.5 mbar) and H2O (0.5 mbar) at 648 K. The XPS spectra were processed with the KolXPD software by subtracting the Shirley background and using Voigt profiles for fitting. The acid properties of the samples were estimated by pyridine adsorption followed by Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy. Before pyridine adsorption, the samples pressed into thin wafers at ∼x223C1 ton•cm−2 were heat-treated at 698 K and evacuated for 1 h. The wafers were contacted with gaseous pyridine at 423 K. The spectra were recorded after pyridine desorption by evacuation at 423, 523 and 623 K using a Spectrum One FTIR spectrometer (Perkin Elmer, USA) with a spectral resolution of 1 cm−1 and 24 scans per one spectrum. These spectra were recalculated to a “normalized” wafer weight and its surface area. The study of base characteristics of the samples was performed by one-pass temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) of CO2 controlled by mass spectrometry using an ultra-high-vacuum (UHV) installation of the “black chamber” type [32]. It allows complex researches of adsorption-desorption processes on a solid surface to be made in situ. The desorption molecules of CO2 from the samples was controlled by the time-of-flight mass spectrometry (MSX-3-PC “Electron”, Ukraine) and monopole mass spectrometry (MX7304A-PC “Selmi”, Ukraine). The distance between a sample and a mass spectrometry detector is 0.5 cm. Before the adsorption of CO2, the samples with a weight of 20 mg were annealed in vacuum (chamber pressure of 10−9 Torr) at 773 K for 1 h, and then cooled down to room temperature. The adsorption was carried out using CO2 for 12 h. The following desorption procedure was carried out with a heating rate of 0.15 K/sec. The distribution function f(Ea) of the activation energy for CO2 desorption was calculated using the equation described earlier and self-consistent regularization procedure [32,33]. 2.3 Catalytic activity measurement Catalytic activity tests were carried out in a flow quartz reactor at atmospheric pressure. The catalyst weight was 0.16 g; the grain size was 0.25–0.5 mm. Ethanol (96 and 80 vol%) was fed via a syringe infusion pump. A concentration of 80 vol% ethanol was chosen based on a recent patent of Michelin Recherche et Technique S.A.14 Argon was used as a solvent gas; the flow rate was 420 cm3•h − 1. Before the reaction, the catalysts were kept at 773 K in an argon flow for 1 h. Reagents and reaction products were analysed on a KrystalLux 4000 M gas chromatograph (MetaChrome, Russia) equipped with a flame ionization detector and a capillary column (HP-FFAP, 50 m× 0.32 mm). Catalytic properties of the samples were characterized by EtOH conversion (X), selectivity to products (Si), product yield (Yi) and BD productivity (PBD) calculated using the following formulas: (1) X = n EtOH 0 − n EtOH n EtOH 0 − 100 % , (2) S i = n i ( n EtOH 0 − n EtOH ) · 100 % , (3) Y i = X · S i 100 % , (4) P BD = Y BD · WHSV · 0.587 100 % , where n0 EtOH is the initial amount of C moles of EtOH; nEtOH and ni are the amount of C moles of unreacted EtOH and product i in the stream of the reaction products, respectively; WHSV is the weight hourly space velocity, gEtOH•gcat −1•h − 1; 0.587 is the maximum possible amount of BD (g) that can be produced from 1 g of EtOH according to the stoichiometry of the gross-equation: 2C2H5OH → C4H6 +H2 + 2H2O. Carbon balance was calculated as the total carbon amount in the analysed products, divided by the initial total amount of carbon, and it was generally better than 95%. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Microscopic characterizations Fig. 1 presents HR-TEM images of three-component (Cu/Zr-Si, Cu/La-Si) oxide catalysts after ETB process. The images reveal copper, zirconium oxide, and lanthanum hydroxide nanoparticles on the silica surface. The size of copper nanoparticles is estimated to be about 10 nm. The lattice fringes with d-spacing of about 0.208 nm correspond to [1 1 1] planes typical for metallic copper and the lattice fringes with d-spacing of 0.249 nm and 0.211 nm can be assigned to [1 1 1] and [2 0 0] planes of Cu2O evidencing partial surface oxidation of copper nanoparticles. In turn, most of the planes match well with ZrO2 [1 1 1] (0.296 nm) or La(OH)3 [1 1 1] and [2 0 0] (0.320 and 0.281 nm, respectively). As proved by SEM data (ESI, Figure S1), the morphology of three and four-component oxide samples is similar and generally determined by the morphology of silica carrier. The same is observed for ZnLaZrSi oxide systems prepared with a silica component of different nature [23]. SEM-EDX and TEM-EDX mapping for three and four component oxide samples under study has been collected (ESI, Figures S2 and S3) to evaluate the distribution of active components over the silica surface. Copper is evenly distributed on the surface of all samples without any large agglomerations at the macroscale. Zirconium is evenly distributed on the surface of Cu/Zr-Si sample. For Cu/La-Si sample, there are areas of lanthanum accumulation. For four component samples, the introduction order affects the distribution of active components over the surface. The signal of Zr for Cu/La-Zr-Si is lower than that for Cu/Zr-La-Si, which may result from the blocking of a part of the zirconium oxide species by lanthanum species, as proved by both SEM-EDX and TEM-EDX mapping. As for Cu/La-Si sample, there are areas of lanthanum accumulation on the Cu/La-Zr-Si surface (SEM-EDX mapping, ESI, Figure S2), while lanthanum is highly dispersed over the surface at the nanoscale (TEM-EDX mapping, ESI, Figure S3). On the surface of Cu/Zr-La-Si sample La atoms are distributed uniformly. 3.2 DR UV–Vis characterizations The DR UV–Vis spectra of Cu/Zr-Si and Cu/La-Si catalysts (Fig. 2 ) are composed of the bands at 207 (or 214 nm, depending on the sample), about 255, and 435 nm, as well as the shoulder at 295 nm. The bands at 207 and 214 nm are assigned to electronic transitions in the Zr-Si and La-Si oxide systems. The band at 255 nm and the shoulder at 295 nm may be assigned to charge transfer O2− → Cu2+ transitions of oxidized copper species, while the bands at 435 nm could be attributed to charge transfer in oligomeric [Cu–O–Cu] n + units and metallic nanoparticles [34–36]. The stabilization of copper in the oxidized state in the catalyst composition after catalytic reaction in a reducing atmosphere of ethanol may result from the interaction of copper with the Zr-Si and La-Si oxide surface. The differences in the intensity of the bands for Cu/Zr-Si and Cu/La-Si samples are noted to be insignificant. Similar differences in DR UV–Vis spectra were previously observed for silver-containing Ag/Zr-Si and Ag/La-Si catalysts [37]. 3.3 Acid-base properties The acid properties of two (Zr-Si, La-Si), three (Cu/Zr-Si, Cu/La-Si) and four (Cu/Zr-La-Si, Cu/La-Zr-Si) component oxide catalysts are investigated by FTIR spectroscopy of adsorbed pyridine (Fig. 3 ). There are following bands that indicate the Lewis acid sites (LAS) in the spectra. The bands at 1449–1448 cm−1 can be attributed to Zr and La containing LAS [38–40], while the bands at 1452 cm−1 can be attributed to Cu-containing LAS [41,42]. By comparing the band intensities, the amount of LAS in Zr-containing samples is concluded to be higher than in La-containing ones. An increase of pyridine desorption temperature from 423 K to 523 K results in a decrease in intensity of the bands at 1449–1448 cm−1 and disappearance of the bands at 1452 cm−1 in the spectra of Zr-containing samples, while in the spectra of La-Si and Cu/La-Si the bands at both 1448 cm−1 and 1452 cm−1 practically disappear. Therefore, medium and strong LASs are formed only with the participation of Zr(IV). There are only weak (the pyridine desorption temperature up to 423 K) acid sites formed with the participation of lanthanum and copper. The acidity of the catalysts containing both zirconium and lanthanum is comparable to that of Cu/Zr-Si sample. The introduction order of lanthanum and zirconium into the sample somewhat affects the shape and intensity of the bands indicating LAS. For example, higher intensity of the bands at 1449 cm−1 is observed for Cu/Zr-La-Si sample. A similar effect of the catalyst component introduction order on acid properties of 5%ZrO2–5%La2O3/MCM-41 systems has been noted earlier [43]. Fig. 4 shows one-pass temperature-programmed desorption profiles of CO2 for the samples under study. The base characteristics of the samples, namely basicity and activation energy of CO2 desorption (Ea), have been calculated based on deconvoluted TPD profiles for each peak separately (see ESI, Figure S4) and are summarized in Table 1 . For all samples, the maximum of СО2 desorption is observed in the low-temperature region (≤400 K, Ea ≥100 kJ•mol−1), which is in accordance with previous observations [44,45]. For La-Si oxide systems, CO2 molecules can adsorb on coordinatively unsaturated La(III) sites of the silicate surface and bound to OH-groups [45]. The CO2-TPD profiles of copper-containing samples exhibit additional high-temperature desorption peaks. The high value of the activation energy of CO2 desorption more likely evidences the formation of surface copper bicarbonates than the strong copper-containing base sites. The modification of Zr-Si oxide system with copper also promotes the formation of weak and medium-strong base sites. In contrast, the modification of La-Si oxide system with copper leads to a decrease in the number of base sites by about a third, especially medium-strong base sites. This was previously observed for copper-modified MgO-SiO2 and TaSiBEA systems [41,42]. Thereby, a higher amount of base sites is presented over the surface of the La-Si sample than over Zr-Si one, and the same is observed for the corresponding copper-containing systems (Table 1). It can be seen that the introduction order of lanthanum and zirconium affects the basicity of four component oxide samples. The total basicity of Cu/La-Zr-Si sample, including the amount of medium-strong base sites (Ea = 100–200 kJ•mol−1), is a quarter higher than that of Cu/Zr-La-Si sample. La-containing base sites are suggested to be formed by the interaction of La3+ cations with silica. These sites are not blocked by zirconium dioxide when the introduction order would be zirconium followed by lanthanum. Therefore, both acid and base sites are present on the surface of two (Zr-Si, La-Si), three (Cu/Zr-Si, Cu/La-Si) and four (Cu/Zr-La-Si, Cu/La-Zr-Si) component oxide catalysts. Meanwhile, the presence of zirconium in the sample favours the formation of preferably acid sites, while lanthanum promotes the base site formation. The introduction order of zirconium and lanthanum determines acid-base characteristics of the surface of four component oxide samples. 3.4 NAP-XPS characterizations NAP-XPS studies on the three-component oxide catalysts were carried out under EtOH and EtOH+H2O flows to elucidate the active catalyst components under the reaction conditions. NAP-XPS measurements were also performed under H2 flow as a reference spectrum. There was a significant differential charging on the surface of 1 wt.% Cu-containing samples and, thereby, 20 wt.% Cu-containing model samples were prepared and designated as Cu20/Zr-Si and Cu20/La-Si for NAP-XPS measurements. In such samples, copper was assumed to be preferably in a metallic state (after reduction under H2 flow at 648 K) acting as a conductor, and thus the differential charging was expected to decrease. It was also expected that a higher concentration of copper had little impact on the chemical states of zirconium and lanthanum in the samples. Cu 2p NAP-XPS spectra of the model samples under different flows (Figure S5) and their discussion are given in ESI. Fig. 5 presents Zr 3d, O 1 s and Si 2p NAP-XPS spectra of Cu20/Zr-Si under different flows. Under H2 flow, the NAP-XPS spectra exhibit Zr 3d5/2 signal at 182,9 eV, indicative of Zr(IV) in zirconium silicate and [Zr–O–Si] bonds formed by the interaction of ZrO2 nanoparticles and silica [46–48]. The H2O and EtOH exposures do not influence the binding energy of Zr 3d5/2. No separate peaks or shoulders characteristic of Zr–O–Si bonds (expected at about 531.3 and ∼x223C 101.8 eV) [48] and ZrO2 (expected at about 530.0 eV) are observed in the O 1 s and Si 2p spectra. This might be because of low concentration of ZrO2 with respect to SiO2 and thus the signal of SiO2 dominates in the O1s spectrum hiding other states. La 3d, O 1 s and Si 2p NAP-XPS spectra of Cu20/La-Si under different flows are shown in Fig. 6 . Under H2 flow, the spectra exhibit La 3d5/2 signal at 834.7 eV, indicative of La(III) in oxygen- containing compounds [49–51]. The magnitude of the multiplet splitting (ΔE) and the intensity ratio of each multiplet-split component of La 3d5/2 allow to distinguish between La-based chemical compounds. The ΔE value of 3.7 eV is characteristic of lanthanum in hydrated lanthanum oxide, La(OH)3 and [La-O-Si] fragments formed by the interaction of La(III) with silica [50,52–54]. Since the intensity of the main La 3d5/2 signal is higher than that of the signal obtained as result of multiplet splitting, lanthanum is suggested to be bounded with surface hydroxyl groups and silica and rather than to form carbonates or hydroxycarbonates [55–57]. Under EtOH flow, the ΔE value does not change, suggesting the catalyst composition remains intact under the reaction conditions. The presence of La(OH)3 in the catalyst is also consistent with HR-TEM data discussed before (Fig. 1). Under EtOH+H2O flow, the intensity of La 3d5/2 signal increases compared to the satellite. Moreover, an O 1 s shoulder appears at 530.7 eV, indicative of [La-О-Н] in lanthanum-containing coordination compounds [58], and H2O molecules bound to La-silicate film [59]. Therefore, lanthanum can also be hydrated in [La-O-Si] fragments under the reaction conditions. Two La 4d signals at the BE of 102.4 eV (4d5/2) and 105.6 eV (4d3/2), which are superimposed with Si 2p signal, also revealed the presence of La(III) in the Cu20/La-Si composition. However, according to the previous study [49,50], there is no significant position difference of La 4d5/2 signals between La2O3 and La(OH)3. C 1 s NAP-XPS spectra of Cu20/Zr-Si and Cu20/La-Si samples under EtOH and EtOH+H2O flows at 648 K are shown in Fig. 7 . In the spectra of Cu20/Zr-Si there are shoulders indicative of CC (284.1 eV), ethoxy (the combination of methylene (285.4 eV) and alkoxy (287.0 eV) groups), and acetaldehyde species (the combination of methylene (285.9 eV) and carbonyl (288.3 eV) groups) [60–64]. After adding water, the ratio between carbon coke (CC) and ethoxy groups changed. It might be due to occupation of some strong acid sites on the surface by H2O or OH blocking further formation of heavy products resulting from the self- and cross-condensation of alcohols and aldehydes [18,23,65]. In the C 1 s spectra of Cu20/La-Si under EtOH flow there are signals indicative of CC (284.5 eV), ethoxy (the combination of methylene (286.3 eV) and alkoxy (288.2 eV) groups), acetaldehyde species (the combination of methylene (286.7 eV) and carbonyl (288.8 eV) groups). After adding water, there are shifts of signal position of ethoxy (286.3 eV → 286.6 eV and 288.2 eV → 288.5 eV) and acetaldehyde species (286.7 eV → 287.9 eV and 288.8 eV→ 290.0 eV). It may be the result of the interaction of these groups with surface hydroxyl groups, particularly related to La-containing sites. Also, in the C 1 s spectra of both catalysts, the ratio between acetaldehyde and ethoxy species increases. This may be caused by a decrease in the rate of C‒C coupling in the presence of water, a result of which the proportion of uncondensed acetaldehyde in the reaction mixture increases. It is consistent with the results obtained both in this work (Tables 2 and 3 ) and by others authors [16–18]. Therefore, from the NAP-XPS results, it becomes evident that zirconium dioxide interacts with silica on the interface, forming [Zr–O–Si] structures which are Lewis acid sites. In the case of Cu20/La-Si sample, lanthanum is bounded with OH-groups and with oxygen of silica. Differences in the position of signals for acetaldehyde and ethoxy species on the C 1 s spectra may indicate differences in the interaction of these species with surface acid (Zr(IV)) or basic ([La-Ö-H/Si]) sites. 3.5 Catalytic performance of the Cu/La(-Zr)-Si oxide catalysts Fig. 8 shows a change in the product selectivity versus ethanol conversion in the presence of Cu/Zr-Si and Cu/La-Si catalysts. BD selectivity gradually rises for both catalysts with an increase in ethanol conversion up to 50%, and it declines at the conversion above 70%. This tendency was also observed in the presence of other catalysts in the refs [66,67]. The selectivity of butylenes is almost constant. The selectivity of ethylene and DEE gradually declines with an increase in ethanol conversion to 50% and rises at the conversion above 70%, that is, the change in the selectivity is antibatic to the change in BD selectivity. The selectivity of acetaldehyde depends on ethanol conversion insignificantly in the presence of Cu/Zr-Si, while over Cu/La-Si it changes antibatically to BD selectivity. It should be also noted that the maximum BD productivity values are achieved for both catalysts at WHSV = 0.4 gEtOH•gcat −1•h − 1 (598 К). The optimal values WHSV in the range of 0.23–0.45 gEtOH•gcat −1•h − 1 (with an achievement of greater BD selectivity at high ethanol conversion at 598 K) in the ETB process over Ag/ZrO2-SiO2 catalysts are also noted in the works [68, 69]. The temperature dependences of ethanol conversion and yields of the main products in the presence of Cu/Zr-Si and Cu/La-Si catalysts at a constant ethanol load (WHSV = 0.4 gEtOH•gcat −1•h − 1) are presented in Fig. S7. Over Cu/Zr-Si, an increase in the ETB process temperature above 598 K leads only to an increase in ethanol conversion without an increase in BD yield (BD yield is 31.5% at 598 K and 28.9% at 673 K). In turn, some increase in BD yield (from 22.3% to 30.9%) is observed over Cu/La-Si catalyst. Similar changes in ethanol conversion and BD selectivity/yield with increasing temperature were previously reported for Ag/ZrO2-SiO2 [68], Cu/TaSiBEA [42] and ZrZn-La/silica [20] systems. An increase in the ETB process temperature contributes to an increase in ethylene yield from 4.0% to 60.4% over Cu/Zr-Si and from 1.7% to 44.2% over Cu/La-Si, resulting from the process thermodynamics [1,6,70]. Table 2 shows the indices of rectified ethanol (96 vol%) conversion in the presence of two (Zr-Si, La-Si), three (Cu/Zr-Si, Cu/La-Si) and four (Cu/Zr-La-Si, Cu/La-Zr-Si) component oxide catalysts. Ethanol conversion over La-Si sample is much lower than that over Zr-Si, but the values of BD selectivity and yield are higher in the presence of the former. Also, AA selectivity is higher and the selectivity of ethanol dehydration products (ethylene and DEE) is lower in the presence of La-Si sample. These selectivity indices are consistent with acid-base characteristics of two-component oxide catalysts (Zr-Si sample is characterized by a higher acidity, while La-Si sample is characterized by higher basicity). The copper introduction into Zr-Si and La-Si oxide systems leads, as expected, to increase in ethanol conversion and to change in product selectivity towards the formation of more BD, acetaldehyde, butylenes and less ethylene and DEE. In the presence of studied four-component oxide systems, ethanol conversion is lower than over three-component Cu/Zr-Si ones. In the presence of Cu/Zr-La-Si and Cu/La-Si, the comparable values of ethanol conversion and selectivity for the main products are observed. In the presence of Cu/La-Zr-Si the values of ethanol conversion and ethylene selectivity are lower, while BD selectivity is higher than over the others. Four-component oxide systems with a different introduction order of zirconium and lanthanum differ in acid-base properties of the surface, which causes a difference in the values of ethanol conversion and product selectivity. For example, a higher BD selectivity and a lower selectivity of ethanol dehydration products are achieved over Cu/La-Zr-Si catalyst with pronounced base properties. In the presence of a mechanical mixture of the Cu/Zr-Si and Cu/La-Si samples, an increase in the process indices (ethanol conversion, BD selectivity/yield) is not observed. As described for ZnZrLaSi-oxide systems [17,20,23], the combination of zirconium and lanthanum compounds in one catalyst improves the performance of the ETB process from aqueous ethanol. Four-component oxide catalysts containing both zirconium and lanthanum like Cu/Zr-La-Si and Cu/La-Zr-Si are superior to three-component ones (Cu/Zr-Si, Cu/La-Si) in BD selectivity during aqueous ethanol (80 vol%) conversion too (Table 3). Wherein, as during rectified ethanol conversion, the introduction order of zirconium and lanthanum into the catalyst affects the indices of ethanol conversion and product selectivity during the aqueous ethanol conversion. Higher selectivity values of BD and acetaldehyde and lower ones of ethylene and DEE during the aqueous ethanol conversion over Cu/La-Zr-Si sample is probably resulted from higher basicity of the latter's surface. The formation of La-containing base sites on the surface of Cu/Zr-La-Si and Cu/La-Zr-Si catalysts (as shown by the NAP-XPS method) is suggested to be a reason of high BD selectivity achieved during the aqueous ethanol conversion. The feed changes from 96 vol% ethanol to 80 vol% results in the close values of ethanol conversion over all investigated La-containing catalysts. It is likely to be because of the activity of La-containing base sites on the catalyst surface under both ethanol and aqueous ethanol flows. Moreover, the presence of a larger number of La-containing sites on the Cu/La-Zr-Si surface, as compared to Cu/Zr-La-Si (which is associated with the introduction order of catalyst components), leads to higher selectivity of ethanol dehydrogenation products than dehydration ones. Meanwhile, higher BD selectivity is achieved during the aqueous ethanol conversion over Cu/Zr-La-Si and Cu/La-Zr-Si catalysts, compared to Cu/La-Si. Therefore, Zr-containing LASs are also required for the ETB process, namely aldol condensation of acetaldehyde, as previously observed for ZnZrSi, ZnLaSi, and ZnZrLaSi oxide catalysts [21]. Therefore, the following points can be distinguished regarding the role of lanthanum in the ETB process catalyst. Lanthanum is fixed in the form of hydroxide and surface silicates, forming acid-base pairs [La–Ö–H] and [La–Ö–Si] on the surface. All steps of the ETB process can be carried out on these La-containing sites, which is confirmed by BD formation during rectified ethanol conversion over the La-Si sample. The introduction of the component that accelerates ethanol dehydrogenation reaction (Cu) into La-Si oxide system leads to subsequent conversion of the ethanol-acetaldehyde mixture on the La-containing sites. Most likely, aldol condensation of acetaldehyde and Meerwein–Ponndorf–Verley reduction of crotonaldehyde occur on La-containing base sites, while the dehydration of aldol and crotyl alcohol occurs on weak acid sites of the surface. The additional introduction of the acid component that accelerates the Meerwein–Ponndorf–Verley reduction of crotonaldehyde (Zr) is likely to result in aldol condensation of acetaldehyde on preferably La-containing base sites. Moreover, during the aqueous ethanol conversion in the presence of a four-component (Cu-La-Zr-Si) catalyst, there is a cooperative effect of Zr- and La-containing sites, which are active in the key reaction of the ETB process like aldol condensation of acetaldehyde. Lanthanum in Cu/La(-Zr)-Si-containing systems also increase catalyst resistance to the deactivating action of water. This is a reason to achieve high BD selectivity and yield during the aqueous ethanol conversion, comparable to that achieved during rectified ethanol conversion. 4 Conclusions Three and four-component Cu/La(-Zr)-Si oxide systems are prepared and their acid-base characteristics and catalytic properties in aqueous ethanol conversion into 1,3-butadiene are studied. In the catalyst, acid sites are shown to be preferentially formed with the participation of zirconium, whereas basic sites are formed with the participation of lanthanum. The Cu/La-Zr-Si catalysts are characterized by high (≥65%) 1,3-butadiene selectivity during the conversion of both rectified and aqueous ethanol. Herewith, the catalyst activity depends on the introduction order of the components due to the difference in acid-base characteristics of the surface. According to NAP-XPS results, the positive effect of lanthanum addition into Cu/Zr-Si catalyst can be explained by the formation of lanthanum-containing base sites like [La–Ö–Si] and [La–Ö–H] being tolerant to the action of water. Therefore, a modification of the ETB-process catalysts with lanthanum increases their activity in aqueous ethanol conversion into 1,3-butadiene. The differences in the interaction of reaction intermediates with surface Zr- and La-containing sites are found out by C 1 s NAP-XPS measurements, and the effect of H2O on adsorption of carbon coke, acetaldehyde and ethoxy species over the catalyst surface is shown. coredata.dc:description: This paper presents the results of an investigation of three (Cu/La-Si and Cu/Zr-Si) and four (Cu/La-Zr-Si) component oxide systems in aqueous ethanol conversion into 1,3-butadiene, with special accent to the effect of lanthanum in the catalyst composition. The catalysts were characterized by HRTEM, SEM, DR UV−vis, in situ near ambient pressure X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (NAP-XPS), FTIR with pyridine, and TPD-CO2. The high (≥65%) 1,3-butadiene selectivity is achieved during the conversion of both rectified and aqueous ethanol over the studied catalysts. Catalyst activity of the four-component oxide systems depends on an introduction order of the components, which determines acid-base characteristics of the surface. A modification of the Cu/Zr-Si catalyst with lanthanum increases their activity in aqueous ethanol conversion into 1,3-butadiene. The positive effect of lanthanum addition into Cu/Zr-Si catalyst can be explained by the formation of lanthanum-containing base sites like [La–Ö–Si] and [La–Ö–H] being tolerant to the action of water. The differences in the interaction of reaction intermediates with surface Zr- and La-containing sites are found out by C 1 s NAP-XPS measurements, and the effect of H2O on adsorption of carbon coke, ethoxy species and acetaldehyde over the catalyst surface is shown.
coredata.dc:title: The effect of lanthanum in Cu/La(-Zr)-Si oxide catalysts for aqueous ethanol conversion into 1,3-butadiene
